Title: Why is log-of-sum-of-exponentials $f(x)=\log\left(\sum_{i=1}^n e^ {x_i}\right)$ a convex function for $x \in\mathbb R^n$?
Content: How to prove $f(x)=\log\left(\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^n e^{x_i}\right)$ is a convex function? EDIT1: for above function $f(x)$ , following inequalities hold: $$\max\{x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n\}\leqslant f(x)\leqslant\max\{x_1,x_2,\ldots,x_n\}+\log n$$ and I have tried proving its convexity via definition of a convex function with above inequalities, but that didn't work. EDIT2 : I have posted my answers below.
AcceptedAnswer:
Proof: Let $u_i=e^ {x_i} ,v_i=e^ {y_i}$ . So $f(\theta x+(1-\theta)y)=\log(\sum_ {i=1}^n e^{\theta x_i + (1-\theta)y_i})=\log(\sum_ {i=1}^n u_i^ \theta v_i^{(1-\theta)})$ From Hölder's inequality: $$\sum_ {i=1}^n x_iy_i \le (\sum_ {i=1}^n|x_i|^p)^{\frac{1}{p}} \cdot (\sum_ {i=1}^n|y_i|^q)^{\frac{1}{q}}$$ where $1/p+1/q=1$ . Applying this inequality to $f(\theta x+(1-\theta)y)$ : $$\log(\sum_ {i=1}^n u_i^ \theta v_i^{(1-\theta)}) \le 
\log[(\sum_ {i=1}^n u_i^ {\theta \cdot \frac{1}{\theta}})^ \theta \cdot 
(\sum_ {i=1}^n v_i^ {1-\theta \cdot \frac{1}{1-\theta}})^ {1-\theta}]$$ The right formula can be reduced to: $$\theta \log\left(\sum_ {i=1}^n u_i\right)+(1-\theta)\log \left(\sum_ {i=1}^n v_i \right)$$ Here I regard $\theta$ as $\frac{1}{p}$ and $1-\theta$ as $\frac{1}{q}$ . So I achieve that $f(\theta x+(1-\theta)y) \le \theta f(x) + (1-\theta)f(y)$ .
